bib_record.title: Cross sections for the production of helium, neon and argon isotopes by proton-induced reactions on iron nickel.

free_txt: DSM, DAPNIA/SPHN.
University of Cologne, Germany.
LNS, beam energy > 200 MeV
TSL, beam energy < 200 MeV.
.The INC4/ABLA and TALYS model.
Before calculating cross sections the measured noble
gas concentrations have to be corrected for mass
fractionation, interferences, blanks and trapped air.
Sensitivities and mass fractionation factors were
determined by peak height comparisons with signals from
known amounts of He, Ne and Ar, respectively.
Absolute calibration of the mass spectrometer was
made.
The total uncertainties include the statistic
and systematic uncertainties-
the statistical uncertainties of the noble gas
measurement, blank corrections, interference
corrections, corrections for sensitivity changes and
atmospheric contamination.
The systematic uncertainty
of the noble gas concentrations is 5%.
The monitor
reaction cross sections yield given an additional
uncertainty of 7%.
LNS, beam energy > 200 MeV
TSL, beam energy < 200 MeV.
Mass spectrometers University of Bern and
University of Bordeaux.
The irradiated Fe and Ni foils were analysed on
two non-commercial mass spectrometers, one sector
field instrument for the measurement of He and Ne
isotopes and one tandem spectrometer for the
measurement of Ar isotopes.
After a necessary cooling, all noble gases were
measured in University of Bordeaux.
For proton energies above 200 MeV the mini-stack
approach was used to reduce secondary particle
effects.
At TSL the stacks-foil technique was used, since the
influences of secondary  particle on the production of
the residual nuclides can be neglected in this energy
range.
.Weight in mg.
- data
for Bi(p,x) reactions
revised data
for reaction
PB-0(P,X)2-HE-3 were given in O0839 subent 002
revised data
for reaction
12-Mg(P,X)2-HE-3 given in O0520002, for one
13-Al(p,x)2-HE-3 given in O0520008 and for reaction
14-Si(p,x)2-HE-3 given in O0520014.
High-purity materials were used as targets. Each
target was carefully cleaned and weighted before
irradiation. The mass of the individual Fe and Ni
targets with diameters of 15 mm or 15.7 mm were between
40-mg/cm**2 and 220 mg/cm**2.
